data.meaning_mnemonic:
A young <kanji>woman</kanji> who is planting rice from <kanji>early</kanji> morning into the <kanji>latter</kanji> evenings is a <vocabulary>rice planting girl</vocabulary>. You'll see them out there all day long, from dawn till dusk, planting, taking care of, and picking rice.

This is also a common family name, and on rare occasion, a given name as well. Some well-known people with this name include historical fiction writer Saotome Mitsugu (<ja>早乙女 貢</ja>), former pro-wrestler, model, and idol Saotome Miku (<ja>早乙女 未来</ja>), and stage and screen actor Saotome Taichi (<ja>早乙女 太一</ja>).
data.reading_mnemonic:
This is a really weird exception, sorry. You've kind of learned these reading, but they're like... weird variations of them.

Take the <ja>さ</ja> from <ja>早速</ja>, the <ja>おつ</ja> becomes <ja>おと</ja>, and then the <ja>女</ja> kun'yomi <ja>め</ja> (hey that one's normal!). And you get <ja>さおとめ</ja>. You might need to just memorize this one.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Remember how you learned that <ja>凹凸</ja> means "uneven?" Well spin something uneven around and it's still <vocabulary>uneven</vocabulary>! Just kinda backwards, just like this word!
data.reading_mnemonic:
However, just because the meaning stays the same when you flip it, doesn't mean the reading does. Doing that actually made the reading change from on'yomi to kun'yomi readings! You haven't learned either of these yet so here's a mnemonic to help you:

When you have the convex parts first and the concave parts second in something <vocabulary>uneven</vocabulary> it ends up looking like a <reading>deco box</reading> (<ja>でこぼこ</ja>). An art deco box that is. They have lots of stuff stick out of them on the outside, but you can open them up and put stuff on the inside.

data.reading_mnemonic:
This is a single kanji with no okurigana, so it's using the kun'yomi reading. You don't know this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You go down to the <vocabulary>harbor</vocabulary> and speak the secret password <reading>me natto</reading> (<ja>みなと</ja>) to buy some fresh natto. Imagine the salty air hitting your face as you whisper, "me natto." Now eat that yummy natto by the water! Mmmm!

context_sentences.en: I would like to visit the port city of Veracruz.
context_sentences.ja: ベラクルスという港町に行ってみたいです。

context_sentences.en: There was a mysterious ship drifting in the harbor.
context_sentences.ja: 不思議な船が港に漂着した。

data.meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>God</kanji> (<kanji>formal name ender</kanji>) is <vocabulary>God</vocabulary>! Or the <vocabulary>gods</vocabulary>, if you're talking to more than one. You have to be polite to them, so you add that ender on there.
data.reading_mnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned them both already so you should be able to read this too!

context_sentences.en: Who comes to your mind when you hear the name "guitar god."

context_sentences.en: That's probably just the god of mischief.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Remember how <ja>文化</ja> means "culture?" Well add <kanji>festival</kanji> to it and you end up with a <vocabulary>culture festival</vocabulary>! These happen all the time at Japanese schools, so sometimes they're called <vocabulary>school festival</vocabulary>s too.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You've learned all of these readings already, good for you!

context_sentences.en: Please come visit my school’s culture festival!
context_sentences.ja: うちの学校の文化祭にもあそびに来てくださいね。

context_sentences.en: "What time should we start the school festival rehearsal?" "I'm available all day long, so anytime that suits you best."
context_sentences.ja: 「文化祭の練習、何時にする？」「おれは一日中ひまだから、そっちの都合の良い時なら何時でもいいよ。」

context_sentences.en: We've assessed administrative and overhead fees at about 35 percent of the total culture festival costs.
context_sentences.ja: 文化祭の管理諸経費は全体の約三十五パーセントになると見積っています。

data.meaning_mnemonic:
If you say something is going to <kanji>clear up</kanji>, you're usually talking about the weather. That makes it <vocabulary>clear weather</vocabulary>.

This can also mean <vocabulary>formal</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>public</vocabulary>. After all, you'll want anything formal or public to happen when it's clear weather! And finally, you can use it to say that someone has been <vocabulary>cleared of suspicion</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

context_sentences.en: The weather forecast said that it will be clear tomorrow, a day after tomorrow, and two days from now.
context_sentences.ja: 天気予ほうでは、明日も明後日も明々後日も晴れでしょうって言ってたよ。

context_sentences.en: The forecast says "clear weather, with clouds later on," so I don't think you need an umbrella.
context_sentences.ja: 予ほうは「晴れ後くもり」だし、かさはいらないんじゃない？

context_sentences.en: It’s a good thing it’s clear out on your birthday, eh?
context_sentences.ja: 折角の誕生日だし、晴れて良かったですね。

data.meaning_mnemonic: If your people can <kanji>relax</kanji> because you <kanji>rule</kanji> over them so well, there is <vocabulary>public order</vocabulary>. You don't want the people you rule being upset or stressed out, you want <vocabulary>public safety</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>public peace</vocabulary> for all!
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context_sentences.en: This area doesn’t have bad public safety, but that area does.
context_sentences.ja: この辺りは治安も悪くないけど、あの辺りは治安が良くないからね。

context_sentences.en: Viet's boss was arrested for disturbing the peace.

context_sentences.en: The other day I saw Koichi, drunk, boastfully telling people that he's actually Superman and he's the one who keeps the peace around here.
context_sentences.ja: こないだ、酔っ払ったコウイチが、「俺は実はスーパーマンなんだ。この辺りの治安を守っているのはこの俺様なんだ」って豪語していたよ。

data.meaning_mnemonic: Remember how you learned that <ja>昨日</ja> means "yesterday?" Well <kanji>one</kanji> day <kanji>previous</kanji> to that <kanji>day</kanji> is the <vocabulary>day before last</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic:
This reading is an exception. Let's use this mnemonic to remember it:

The <vocabulary>day before last</vocabulary> you bought an <reading>"O" toe toy</reading> (<ja>おととい</ja>). It's a kid's toy in the shape of the letter O that you put on your toe. You know it was the day before last because you wore it all yesterday, and now today your toe is sore. If only you could go back to the <vocabulary>day before yesterday</vocabulary> to tell yourself not to buy that O toe toy! Or at least not to wear it for the whole next day!

context_sentences.en: It's a bit late, but the day before yesterday, May 5, was Luffy's birthday.
context_sentences.ja: 今さらですが一昨日の5月5日はルフィのたん生日でした。

context_sentences.en: I was available the day before last, but this month all of my other days are entirely full already.
context_sentences.ja: 一昨日だったら空いてたんだけど、今月は他の日は全てうまってしまってるんだよね。

context_sentences.en: The day before last I caught my husband cheating on me.
context_sentences.ja: 一昨日、夫の不倫現場を見てしまったんです。

data.meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <ja>う</ja> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>prohibition</kanji> so the verb version means <vocabulary>to prohibit</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to forbid</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

context_sentences.en: This is an autobiographical novel that Koichi wrote about his own forbidden love.

context_sentences.en: The doctor forbade the pregnant woman from alcohol and cigarettes.

context_sentences.en: In this room, whispering is prohibited.

data.meaning_mnemonic:
Remember when you learned that <ja>高等</ja> means "high class" and <ja>学校</ja> means "school?" Well put them together and you have <vocabulary>senior high school</vocabulary>! It's the most high class school you've got (unless you go to university, but that's considered to be separate). 

Fun fact: <ja>高校</ja> is the abbreviation of this word. Neat, right?
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context_sentences.en: Right after graduating from his senior high school, Koichi joined the navy.
context_sentences.ja: コウイチは高等学校を卒業してすぐ海軍に入りました。

context_sentences.en: There was a senior high school that was famous for celebrities going there, near the condo I used to live in when I was little.
context_sentences.ja: 私がまだ小さかった時に住んでいたマンションの近くに芸能人が通うことで有名な高等学校がありました。

context_sentences.en: I’m the vice principal of a senior high school.
context_sentences.ja: 高等学校で教頭をしております。

data.meaning_mnemonic:
If your <kanji>eye</kanji>s are <kanji>awake</kanji> then you're going <vocabulary>to wake up</vocabulary>. Your eyes are usually the first thing to awaken when you're waking up, you know? 

This word can also mean <vocabulary>to awaken</vocabulary> but it's like when you to come to your senses, not literally waking up.
data.reading_mnemonic:
The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You haven't learned this reading for <ja>覚</ja> yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

If you start <vocabulary>to wake up</vocabulary> in the middle of the night, it's because of the wake up wi<reading>za</reading>rd (<ja>ざ</ja>). He sneaks into your house when you're sleeping and pokes you with his wand. Wizards like when you wake up. They're weird.

context_sentences.en: I use this lifehack in the morning so I can wake up properly.

data.meaning_mnemonic:
Some people <kanji>have</kanji> a <kanji>difficult</kanji> time saying <vocabulary>thank you</vocabulary>. But not you now that you know how!

This is often written in kana, so you don't need to use the kanji when writing. But you'll sometimes see the kanji used so it's important to be able to recognize them! Did you know this is an abbreviation of <ja>有難うございます</ja>? You can also spell it like this: <ja>有難う</ja>.
data.reading_mnemonic: You've heard people say <ja>ありがとう</ja> before right?!

context_sentences.en: Thanks to you, I've been accused of tax evasion.

data.meaning_mnemonic: When someone asks you <ja>何故</ja>, or "why," you did something, you respond with, "<ja>何故なら</ja> blah blah blah." That makes it mean <vocabulary>because</vocabulary>. Why did you do that? Because I was mad! Why did you dance? Because I was happy!
data.reading_mnemonic: This reading is an exception but you learned them already because they're the same as the word <ja>何故</ja>, which you learned a few levels ago. It just has some kana attached to it!

data.meaning_mnemonic: Remember how you learned that <ja>迷う</ja> means "to go astray" or "to get lost?" Well when you feel like you're about to go astray or get lost it causes <vocabulary>hesitation</vocabulary>. You end up with a lot of <vocabulary>doubt</vocabulary> about where to go or what to do. It's a natural progression.
data.reading_mnemonic: You learned this reading already when you learned <ja>迷う</ja>! Just swap the <ja>う</ja> for an <ja>い</ja>.

context_sentences.en: I managed to get rid of my hesitation.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <ja>の</ja> particle makes it so the <ja>人</ja> belongs to the <ja>女</ja>. Basically, this literally means "a woman person" or "a person of woman." It's a more polite way to say plain old woman, though, so all you have to remember is that.
data.reading_mnemonic: This word is actually two separate words combined with a particle. So, since you treat them like separate words, you read each of them with the kun'yomi readings (they are both single kanji words all alone). That being said, in level 1 you learned about the vocab readings for these separate words, so use that knowledge to remember the reading for this word as well.

data.reading_mnemonic:

When you need a <vocabulary>radical</vocabulary> to make a new kanji, you just press a button and the radical comes tumbling down the radical <reading>chu</reading>te (<ja>しゅ</ja>). There's definitely no rhyme or reason to radical picking, it's just whatever pops out of the ol' chute.

auxiliary_meanings.meaning: To Make A Mistake On Something

data.meaning_mnemonic:
Remember how <ja>間違い</ja> means "a mistake?" Well this is the verb version. It means <vocabulary>to make a mistake</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to confuse</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to mistake</vocabulary>.

This verb is transitive. That means that it takes a direct object. Bear in mind that this one is a bit tricky, though, because although it's transitive in Japanese, the English translation will sometimes be intransitive.
data.reading_mnemonic: It's read the same as <ja>間違い</ja>! Nice and easy!

data.meaning_mnemonic:
This meaning is a little weird, but I'm going to try my best to help you remember. 

Every <kanji>person</kanji> has to <kanji>participate</kanji> in eating <vocabulary>carrots</vocabulary>. I don't care if you don't like them, if you don't eat at least one carrot in your life you'll die. So if you're a person you better participate in the eating of at least a single carrot.
data.reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for <ja>参</ja> yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You're craving a <vocabulary>carrot</vocabulary>, but you can't seem to find any. You look in your fridge, in your garden, and even in the trash. Finally you give up your carrot search and sit down when... ouch! The carrot was in your <reading>jean</reading>s (<ja>じん</ja>) the whole time!

This word is pretty old, and it's used like a noun with <ja>と</ja>(<ja>して</ja>) added to make it an adverb or <ja>たる</ja> added to make it an adjective. Make sure to check out the context sentences to get more familiar with this classical word.

You can't just tell one <vocabulary>lie</vocabulary>, it always turns into <reading>two</reading> (<ja>つ</ja>). Kind of like a chip or pretzel, you can't just have one. With lies, you have to open your mouth for two more. And then two more.... and... well you get it.

Since this word is made up of a single kanji (and is a body part) it uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Remember the mnemonic from when you first learned this kanji? Well <ja>こういち</ja> is still in your <kanji>throat</kanji> and he doesn't want to get out. In fact, every time you tug on him, he shouts, "<reading>No Do</reading>- (<ja>のど</ja>)" but you gag and can't hear the rest. People around you think you're saying "No Do-" but it's really just the weirdo living in your throat now. What a pain...

data.meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji means <kanji>strangle</kanji> and this vocab is the verb version of that: <vocabulary>to strangle</vocabulary>. t’s usually used in the phrase <ja>首を絞める</ja>, which also means “to strangle.” 

There is another word, <ja>絞る</ja> which means "to wring out" that looks very similar. You know that this one is "to strangle" because it has <ja>める</ja> sticking out of it. Imagine that in the <reading>mail</reading> (<ja>める</ja>) you get a letter that says "I'm going <vocabulary>to strangle</vocabulary> you!" When you get this in the mail, you know it's about strangling.
data.reading_mnemonic: The thing that is threatening <vocabulary>to strangle</vocabulary> you is actually a <reading>shee</reading>p (<ja>し</ja>)! The sheep comes to your house and says, "here's the sheep mail!" and then tries to strangle you. It puts its hard feet on your neck though it's pretty ineffective.

data.reading_mnemonic:
So this <vocabulary>enchanting</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>charming</vocabulary> feeling is <vocabulary>mysterious</vocabulary>... some would say <ja>怪しい</ja> (suspicious). It actually shares the same reading as <ja>怪しい</ja>. They're kind of similar, too. Here's the difference:

<ja>怪しい</ja> usually has a negative feel to it whereas <ja>妖しい</ja> generally has a positive feel. <ja>妖しい</ja> also feels more mysterious or has a magical edge.

data.meaning_mnemonic:

This is an intransitive verb, so this verb means <vocabulary>to be split</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to be torn</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to burst apart</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic:
Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading.

Lucky for you, the kanji readings for transitive and intransitive verbs are almost always the same. Once you learn one, you know them both! This reading is the same as <ja>裂く</ja>.

data.meaning_mnemonic:

This is a transitive verb. That means it takes a direct object. The kanji itself means <kanji>approach</kanji>, and the verb version is about making or letting something approach. That's why it means <vocabulary>to move something close to</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to pull something over</vocabulary>, and also <vocabulary>to contribute something</vocabulary>.

data.meaning_mnemonic:

If you <kanji>obtain</kanji> something, you'll want it <vocabulary>to fit inside</vocabulary> your bag. Otherwise how can you take it home? Depending on the context, this verb can also mean <vocabulary>to settle down</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>to be finished</vocabulary>. 

Like most verbs with <ja>まる</ja> as okurigana, this is an intransitive verb. That means it happens by itself, with no emphasis on the person or thing that's making something fit inside, or settle down.

data.meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <ja>う</ja> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>revolve</kanji>, and the verb version is when you make something revolve. You roll it. That's why this verb is <vocabulary>to roll something</vocabulary>.

This is a transitive verb. That means you roll something else, like a ball. Or, if you're a dung beetle, poop. 💩 Not to be confused with <ja>転がる</ja>, which is intransitive, like so many verbs ending in <ja>がる</ja>.
data.reading_mnemonic:
You learned this reading when you learned <ja>転がる</ja>, but here's a mnemonic anyway just in case:

When you try <vocabulary>to roll something</vocabulary>, the outside bits may be moving, but its <reading>core</reading> (<ja>ころ</ja>) stays still. Picture yourself making the earth roll across the floor. The outside parts where the people live are spinning round and round, but the earth's core is in exactly the same place.

context_sentences.ja: カンジュースを転がした。

context_sentences.ja: Dung beetleは、フンを転がすことから「フンコロガシ」と言います。

data.meaning_mnemonic:

The kanji itself means <kanji>suffer</kanji>, and the verb is all about when you make someone else suffer. That's why it's <vocabulary>to hurt someone</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to torment</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to harass</vocabulary>.

You need to differentiate this from <ja>苦しむ</ja>, which is about when YOU suffer. You can remember that <ja>苦しめる</ja> is about making someone else suffer with this mnemonic: Who made you suffer? She (<ja>し</ja>) made me (<ja>め</ja>) suffer! She's so mean!

It is an intransitive verb, like most verbs ending in <ja>わる</ja>. That means that it happens by itself, or at least the cause of the adding is not you. Something gets added to something else, perhaps by magic?

data.meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <ja>う</ja> sound, you know this word is a verb.

The kanji <ja>点</ja> means <kanji>point</kanji>, but this verb actually means <vocabulary>to be lit</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be ignited</vocabulary>. Think of it this way, when a flashlight turns on, it points a beam, of light.

You already learned <ja>点ける</ja>, which is for when you turn something on. <ja>点く</ja>, on the other hand, is an intransitive verb. That means it happens by itself. Like, "Oh look! The lights came on! That's cool (<ja>く</ja>)!"
data.reading_mnemonic:
You already learned this reading when you learned <ja>点ける</ja> but here's a mnemonic just in case:

data.meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <ja>う</ja> sound, you know this word is a verb.

The kanji <ja>受</ja> means <kanji>accept</kanji> and this verb is related. It means <vocabulary>to get accepted</vocabulary>, usually into something good like a university or a new job. It can also mean <vocabulary>to succeed</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to pass</vocabulary>, often in the context of a test or an exam. 

This is an intransitive verb, meaning it happens on its own. The <ja>かる</ja> ending is a hint, because verbs with <ja>かる</ja> as okurigana (kana added to the kanji) are usually intransitive.

Watch out: whereas in English we'd say "to pass an exam", in Japanese it's <ja>試験に受かる</ja>, or "to pass in an exam". That's why it's intransitive in Japanese, even though we might make it transitive in the English translation!
data.reading_mnemonic:
Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading. Here's a little mnemonic to help ya remember:

You open up your acceptance letter and shout "OOOO!!!" (<ja>う</ja>). You passed!

context_sentences.ja: やった！シアトル市の大学に受かったよ！

context_sentences.en: If you don't pass next time, you'll have fewer chances of becoming a doctor.
context_sentences.ja: 次回受からなければ、医者になれるチャンスは少なくなるよ。

context_sentences.en: I made a resolution that I won't go out on weekends until I pass my exams.

You're going <vocabulary>to change something</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to revise something</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to correct something</vocabulary>. data.meaning_mnemonic:

The kanji <ja>外</ja> means <kanji>outside</kanji>, and the meaning of this verb is somewhat related. It means <vocabulary>to disconnect something</vocabulary>. Think of it like this, if you disconnect a plug from a socket, you are taking the plug "outside" of the socket, right? Depending on the context, this verb can also mean <vocabulary>to miss something</vocabulary> (like the target during archery practice), <vocabulary>to remove something</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to exclude something</vocabulary>.

This is a transitive verb. That means it takes a direct object. You disconnect something, like a plug, or remove something, like your dog's leash. It's worth mentioning that most verbs ending in <ja>す</ja> are transitive, so you'll start seeing this pattern as you learn more!

To help you distinguish this from <ja>温める</ja>, you could think of a circle (<ja>まる</ja>) rolling down a hill all by itself, and getting warmer and warmer as it picks up speed.

data.meaning_mnemonic:
Because the hiragana ends with an <ja>う</ja> sound, you know this word is a verb. 

The kanji itself means <kanji>deposit</kanji>, and you already learned a similar word that means the same thing as the kanji, <ja>預ける</ja>. With this verb, someone is depositing something (or someone) with you, because they want you <vocabulary>to look after</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to take care of</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to hold on to</vocabulary> it.

To differentiate it with <ja>預ける</ja>, think of the <ja>か</ja> in <ja>預かる</ja>. The only thing you're willing to look after is your <reading>car</reading> (<ja>か</ja>), and nothing else! Someone asks you to look after their kids? Sorry, nothing doing, you're busy taking care of your car. Can you hold on to someone's luggage for them? Nope, your car takes priority.
data.reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this before with the pair verb <ja>預ける</ja>, but here's a mnemonic to remind you just in case:

You need someone <vocabulary>to look after</vocabulary> your kids for the day. Hey I have an idea! Leave them with the monkeys at <reading>a zoo</reading> (<ja>あず</ja>)! Monkeys love kids, and kids love monkeys. Now you can zoom off in your <reading>car</reading>s (<ja>か</ja>) for the day!

data.meaning_mnemonic:
You know that <ja>山</ja> means mountain. Add the hiragana <ja>びこ</ja> to the end and this gives you <vocabulary>echo</vocabulary>. That's because bee children (bee <ja>子</ja>) love echos, especially <vocabulary>mountain echo</vocabulary>s! Imagine baby bees buzzing as loudly as they can and hearing their voices echoing back at them through the mountains.

As the kanji suggests, <ja>山びこ</ja> is generally used to describe the echo you get if you shout in the mountains. To decribe other types of echo, you can use the katakana word <ja>エコー</ja>.

By the way, there is actually a kanji for the second part of this word, but it's so rare that it's usually written in kana!
data.reading_mnemonic: You learned this kanji reading when you learned the vocabulary <ja>山</ja>.

context_sentences.ja: 山びこが聞こえる！

context_sentences.en: I said "yoo-hoo" and "yoo-hoo" came echoing back at me.

data.meaning_mnemonic:
You've hopefully already learned that <ja>力</ja> means "power". You might have also heard the word <ja>いっぱい</ja>, because it's used a lot in conversation. It has a few meanings (you'll learn more of them later) but the important one here is "full" or "a lot". Put these two words together and you have <vocabulary>full power</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>with all one’s strength</vocabulary>, and <vocabulary>as hard as one can</vocabulary>. Remember this one with all your strength!

Just a side note: <ja>いっぱい</ja> can also be written in kanji, which you'll learn later on! However, in simple words like this one it's usually written in kana.
data.reading_mnemonic: <ja>力</ja> uses the same reading as you learned with the vocabulary. That's because this is basically two separate words stuck together.

context_sentences.ja: リレーでは力いっぱいはしりました。

data.meaning_mnemonic: First we have a katakana word, so it's safe to assume that it's a loan word. Like many loan words, it comes from English. Say it out loud and what do you have? That's right, "table". Then comes the particle <ja>の</ja>, which joins two nouns together. Finally we have <ja>上</ja>, which you learned means "up" or "above". Put all of these pieces together and we have a phrase meaning <vocabulary>on the table</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>tabletop</vocabulary>!
data.reading_mnemonic: In this phrase, <ja>上</ja> is a standalone word, so it uses the same reading that you learned when you learned the vocabulary. Easy to stay on top of that one, right?

context_sentences.en: The book is on the table.
context_sentences.ja: 本はテーブルの上にあります。

context_sentences.en: Please put three glasses on the table.

context_sentences.en: I cleaned the table earlier.
context_sentences.ja: さっき、テーブルの上をきれいにしたよ。

data.meaning_mnemonic: This starts with another katakana word, so you can assume that it's a loan word. This one also comes from English. Can you figure out what it means? That's right, "bed". Then comes the particle <ja>の</ja>, which joins two nouns together. Finally, we have <ja>下</ja>, which you learned means "down" or "below". Put these elements together and you get <vocabulary>below the bed</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>under the bed</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>beneath the bed</vocabulary>. What's under your bed?
data.reading_mnemonic: <ja>下</ja> is a standalone word here, so it uses the same reading that you learned when you learned the vocabulary.

data.meaning_mnemonic:
You've already learned that <ja>口</ja> means "mouth" and here it's followed by the particle <ja>に</ja>, which pinpoints a location. The verb <ja>する</ja> means "to do" so you're doing something to your mouth! Logically enough, this expression is used to describe lots of actions that you do with your mouth. It's often used to mean <vocabulary>to mention</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to say</vocabulary>, but with an added descriptive nuance that you've said something accidentally or unexpectedly, maybe something you shouldn't have said! 🙊

It can also mean other things done with the mouth, like <vocabulary>to eat</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>to drink</vocabulary>!
data.reading_mnemonic: In this expression, <ja>口</ja> is a standalone vocabulary word, so it uses the same reading that you learned when you learned the vocabulary.

It can also be read using the on'yomi, though, in which case it has a more formal feel to it. That's typical of on'yomi, which tends to add formality to a word!

data.meaning_mnemonic:
Grab your <kanji>noodle</kanji> <kanji>pole</kanji> and let's make some noodles. What's a noodle pole? It's a <vocabulary>rolling pin</vocabulary>!

You use your rolling pin to flatten out the noodle dough before you slice it into noodles. That's why a rolling pin is so important to make noodles.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. So just keep rolling.

data.meaning_mnemonic:
If you're going to <kanji>abduct</kanji> some <kanji>noodles</kanji>, make sure it's everybody's favorite noodles, <vocabulary>ramen</vocabulary>! The other meaning of the first kanji actually makes more sense here though, because you <kanji>pull</kanji> the dough to stretch it when you make <vocabulary>ramen noodles</vocabulary>. Choose whichever meaning helps you remember it best!

This word is mostly written in kana, usually as ラーメン, but sometimes らーめん. You'll see the kanji version pretty often on packaging and menus, though, so it's worth knowing! The word is also occasionally written as らー麺.
data.reading_mnemonic: Both of these kanji take the on'yomi, but the first one has a slightly irregular reading, because it's based on the modern Chinese reading. To remember that it's a long <ja>らー</ja>, just think how excited you are about these ramen! <reading>Raaaaaa</reading>! Raaaamen! So exciting!

data.meaning_mnemonic: As usual, you can guess this is a verb thanks to the <ja>う</ja> sound on the end. The kanji means <kanji>frustration</kanji>, and unfortunately frustration tends <vocabulary>to torment</vocabulary> people. This verb is pretty advanced, but still useful to know!
data.reading_mnemonic: We all know it's not okay to <vocabulary>to torment</vocabulary> each other. So how about we all <reading>sign a</reading> (<ja>さいな</ja>) contract saying that we'll never torment anyone ever again?

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>heaven</kanji> <kanji>king</kanji> <kanji>star</kanji> is the planet <vocabulary>Uranus</vocabulary>. Knowledge of Greek mythology will definitely help you here, because the English name is a reference to the Greek god of the skies, and the Japanese name is a direct translation of that!
data.reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word and uses the on'yomi, but over time the reading for <ja>王</ja> changed from <ja>おう</ja> to <ja>のう</ja>, to make it easier to pronounce. You'll still see that listed as an alternative reading in some dictionaries, but it's pretty much never used nowadays, so we'll only accept the <ja>てんのうせい</ja> reading. Here's a mnemonic to help you remember:

Who predicted the discovery of <vocabulary>Uranus</vocabulary>? <reading>No</reading>stradamus (<ja>のう</ja>), of course!

context_sentences.en: This in an image of Uranus.
context_sentences.ja: これは天王星の画像です。

context_sentences.en: The discoverer of Uranus is William Herschel.
context_sentences.ja: 天王星の発見者はウィリアム・ハーシェルです。

context_sentences.en: Uranus takes eighty-four years to go around the sun.
context_sentences.ja: 天王星は太陽のまわりを回るのに八十四年かかります.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>fire</kanji> <kanji>star</kanji> is <vocabulary>Mars</vocabulary>. This should be easy to remember, because Mars is the only planet in our solar system that's the color of fire.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context_sentences.en: Olympus Mons is the name of a volcano on Mars.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>tree</kanji> <kanji>star</kanji> is the planet <vocabulary>Jupiter</vocabulary>. Imagine Jupiter covered in very strange trees — the kind that are able to take root in gas! It's a pretty weird image, but will hopefully help you to remember this word. Alternatively, think about how the clouds around Jupiter make patterns that look a lot like wood grain.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context_sentences.en: This is how planets like Jupiter and Saturn were born.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>underworld</kanji> <kanji>king</kanji> <kanji>star</kanji> is the dwarf planet <vocabulary>Pluto</vocabulary>. Since Pluto was the ruler of the underworld in classical mythology, this makes a lot of sense!
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context_sentences.en: Pluto's orbit is irregular, and it takes about 250 years to go around the sun once.

data.meaning_mnemonic:
The <kanji>underworld</kanji> <kanji>world</kanji> is the <vocabulary>underworld</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>Hades</vocabulary>, or the <vocabulary>realm of the dead</vocabulary>.

This word is a bit poetic, and mostly used in writing, particularly in contexts like Buddhism, spirituality, and ancient mythologies. It's usually interchangeable with <ja>冥土</ja> (which is also in this level), but <ja>冥土</ja> is used more in certain set expressions, which we'll mention in the page for that word!
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You learned those with the kanji, so you should be able to read this on your own.

context_sentences.en: Only the souls of the dead can enter the underworld.
context_sentences.ja: 冥界に入れるのは死者の魂だけだ。

context_sentences.en: Hecate is the goddess of the underworld in Greek mythology.
context_sentences.ja: ヘカテーは、ギリシャ神話に出てくる冥界の女神です。

context_sentences.en: I can hear a message from the god of the underworld coming from the realm of the dead.
context_sentences.ja: 冥界から、冥界神のメッセージが聞こえる。

data.meaning_mnemonic:
The <kanji>underworld</kanji> <kanji>dirt</kanji> is another word for the <vocabulary>realm of the dead</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>underworld</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>Hades</vocabulary>. Like the word <ja>冥界</ja> (also in this level), it's rather poetic, and mostly used in written contexts involving spirituality, Buddhism, and ancient mythologies.

There are a few set expressions that only use <ja>冥土</ja>, though. One example is <ja>冥土の土産</ja>, "a souvenir to take to the realm of the dead". It refers to something abstract that is so valuable, it's worth taking to the underworld, such as the solution to a great mystery, or a happy memory.

Another expression is <ja>冥土の旅支度</ja>, which means "preparations for the journey to the realm of the dead", and can refer to the preparation of the deceased before a funeral, as wells as certain preparations made by Buddhists while they're still alive.

You'll also see this word written as <ja>冥途</ja> sometimes.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context_sentences.en: No matter how much money you make, you can't take it with you to the underworld.
context_sentences.ja: どんなにお金を稼いでも、冥土には持っていけないんだよ。

context_sentences.en: "I'll tell you something that'll be your souvenir for the realm of the dead" said the man, and began to tell me his secret, keeping his gun pointing at me.
context_sentences.ja: 「冥土の土産に教えてやるよ。」と、男は銃を構えたまま秘密を話し始めた。

context_sentences.en: After preparing for the journey to the underworld by dressing the body in Buddhist robes and applying makeup for the deceased, they will go on to the next life.
context_sentences.ja: 仏衣や死化粧などの冥土の旅支度をして、故人は来世へと向かいます。

data.meaning_mnemonic: You know that <ja>飲酒</ja> is "drinking alcohol" and <ja>運転する</ja> is "to drive", so it makes sense that this word means <vocabulary>drunk driving</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>drinking and driving</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

data.meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Drink</kanji> <kanji>alcohol</kanji> is <vocabulary>drinking alcohol</vocabulary>, or just <vocabulary>drinking</vocabulary>. This always refers to alcohol though.
data.reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading of <ja>飲</ja> yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Where's a good place for <vocabulary>drinking alcohol</vocabulary>? An <reading>inn</reading> (<ja>いん</ja>), of course!

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>exit</kanji> that <kanji>somebody</kanji> starts from is <vocabulary>one's origin</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>one's hometown</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>one's birthplace</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just watch out for the <ja>つ</ja> of <ja>出</ja>, which becomes <ja>っ</ja>.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You know that the kanji means <kanji>related</kanji>. As a verb, this often means <vocabulary>to be involved</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to be related</vocabulary>, and <vocabulary>to be connected</vocabulary>. Basically, things that have to do with being related to something else.
data.reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  

Ever heard of the "<reading>Kaw Kaw</reading> (<ja>かか</ja>) Crow Gang"? They are bad news, always eating from garbage and squawking "kaw kaw" ... You don't want <vocabulary>to be involved</vocabulary> with them.

data.meaning_mnemonic:
Something that is <kanji>tall</kanji> in <kanji>degree</kanji>s can either refer to its <vocabulary>altitude</vocabulary>, or to the fact that it's quite <vocabulary>high-level</vocabulary>. 

Note that this can refer to any altitude, even lower ones. But when used to refer to, for example, skills or a technique, it always talks about a high level or degree.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

data.meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <ja>う</ja> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>construct</kanji> and the verb version is <vocabulary>to build something</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to construct something</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: As you know, the best way <vocabulary>to build something</vocabulary> is with <reading>kiss</reading>es (<ja>きず</ja>). Kisses build relationships, happy families, and better societies. So get building with those kisses of yours.

context_sentences.en: My dream is to build a happy family with you.
context_sentences.ja: 私の夢は、あなたと幸せな家庭を築くことです。

context_sentences.en: Today, let's all think about what we can do to build a better society.
context_sentences.ja: 今日はみんなで、より良い社会を築くためには何をすればいいかを考えましょう。

data.meaning_mnemonic:
Something that is <kanji>endless</kanji>ly <kanji>big</kanji> isn't just big, but <vocabulary>huge</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>enormous</vocabulary>.

This word is often used in contexts that involve money, but it can also be used for other things like time, energy, and data.

auxiliary_meanings.meaning: To Be In The Service Of

data.meaning_mnemonic:
Everything we're <kanji>doing</kanji> is <vocabulary>to serve</vocabulary> you, you know.

This verb is a bit archaic and therefore has a formal feel to it. It's used to talk about serving emperors, kings, and gods, among others.
data.reading_mnemonic: <vocabulary>To serve</vocabulary> you well, we've gotten ourselves <reading>two ca</reading>rs (<ja>つか</ja>). If one breaks down, we can still serve you with the other car.

auxiliary_meanings.meaning: Falling In Love For The First Time

data.meaning_mnemonic: Your <kanji>first</kanji> <kanji>love</kanji> is your <vocabulary>first love</vocabulary> or your <vocabulary>first crush</vocabulary>. This usually refers to the first time you fall in love, but it can also refer to the person you fall in love with.
data.reading_mnemonic: Similarly to <ja>初耳</ja>, <ja>初</ja> behaves more like a prefix here, which means that this uses kun'yomi readings. You already know these for both <ja>初</ja> and <ja>恋</ja>, so you should be good to go!

meanings.meaning: Something Heard For The First Time

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>first</kanji> time something reaches your <kanji>ear</kanji>, it's <vocabulary>something heard for the first time</vocabulary>. If it's never entered your ear before, it's <vocabulary>news</vocabulary> to you!
data.reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses kun'yomi instead of on'yomi readings, because <ja>初</ja> behaves more like a prefix here. You already know how to read <ja>耳</ja>, but you haven't learned the kun'yomi for <ja>初</ja> yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember it:

Whatever it is, this <vocabulary>something heard for the first time</vocabulary>, be sure to hold onto your <reading>hats</reading> (<ja>はつ</ja>)! It's going to be something big, and I'm pretty sure it's going to be <vocabulary>news</vocabulary> to me, too.

data.meaning_mnemonic: How many <kanji>times</kanji> do I have to tell you that an <kanji>answer</kanji> is an <vocabulary>answer</vocabulary>? Well, okay, it can be a <vocabulary>reply</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>response</vocabulary>, too.
data.reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn the on'yomi for <ja>答</ja> with the kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Give me your <vocabulary>answer</vocabulary> and I'll take you to <ja><reading>とう</reading>きょう</ja>. How does that sound? All I need is your reply, and we'll be in <ja>とうきょう</ja> before you know it.

data.meaning_mnemonic: An <kanji>insect</kanji> <kanji>insect</kanji> is... you guessed it! An <vocabulary>insect</vocabulary>.

Did you know that <vocabulary>insect</vocabulary>s are <reading>Chew</reading>bacca's (<ja>ちゅう</ja>) favorite thing? He's fascinated by all types of insects, and keeps them in boxes as pets. There are a good few of them crawling around in his fur, too.

data.meaning_mnemonic: What <kanji>kill</kanji>s <kanji>insect</kanji>s with one <kanji>dose</kanji>? That's an <vocabulary>insecticide</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>pesticide</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

data.meaning_mnemonic: This is the same <ja>岡山</ja> that you learned with <ja>岡山県</ja>. So what's Okayama <kanji>castle</kanji>? Yep, <vocabulary>Okayama Castle</vocabulary>!
data.reading_mnemonic:
When <ja>城</ja> is added to a place name like this, it takes the on'yomi. You haven't learned this yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

The lord of <vocabulary>Okayama Castle</vocabulary> is none other than <reading>Jourm</reading> (<ja>じょう</ja>). How a farmhand managed to become the lord of a Japanese castle is beyond even us, but it's Lord Jourm to you now.

data.meaning_mnemonic:
A <kanji>person</kanji>'s <kanji>hometown</kanji> is a <vocabulary>human habitation</vocabulary>, or a <vocabulary>village</vocabulary>. This word has a slightly old-fashioned feel, and it's usually used for small villages in the countryside.

It's often combined with <ja>はなれた</ja> (separated) to talk about how far away from the nearest human habitation something is.
data.reading_mnemonic: This jukugo uses the kun'yomi of the kanji instead of the more usual on'yomi. You learned both of these readings when you learned the vocabulary <ja>人</ja> and <ja>里</ja>. Just notice that <ja>さと</ja> becomes <ja>ざと</ja>, because of rendaku.

context_sentences.ja: 人里はなれた山の中からは、月が明るく見える。

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>hometown</kanji> <kanji>potato</kanji> is a <vocabulary>taro</vocabulary>. In Japan, taro is the kind of potato that everyone has in their hometown, because it's been around for such a long time and it'll grow anywhere.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the kun'yomi readings of the kanji.

data.meaning_mnemonic:
The meaning of this word is the same as <ja>任せる</ja>. Both words are pretty common, but <ja>任す</ja> is slightly less common than <ja>任せる</ja>.

Here's the mnemonic again, just in case you need a refresher:

If you pass a <kanji>duty</kanji> on to someone, that means you're going <vocabulary>to entrust something</vocabulary> to that person, or you're going <vocabulary>to delegate something</vocabulary>. In other words, you're going <vocabulary>to leave something to</vocabulary> them, so that they do it for you.
data.reading_mnemonic: This uses the same reading you learned with <ja>任せる</ja>.

context_sentences.en: I'll leave everything about this store to your judgment.
context_sentences.ja: この店のことは全て君の判断に任すよ。

context_sentences.en: I'm happy to be entrusted with a big job, but I'm also a little nervous.
context_sentences.ja: 大きな仕事を任されて、うれしいけど少し不安でもある。

context_sentences.en: I'm Tanaka and I've been assigned as project manager. I look forward to working with you all.
context_sentences.ja: 今回、プロジェクトマネージャーを任されることになった田中です。よろしくお願いします。

data.meaning_mnemonic:
You learned that <ja>我が</ja> means "our", so our <kanji>country</kanji> is simply <vocabulary>our country</vocabulary>.

Just like <ja>我が</ja> itself, this expression is somewhat old-fashioned and stylized. It comes up a lot in political discourse and other formal contexts.
data.reading_mnemonic: You learned this reading for <ja>我</ja> when you learned <ja>我が</ja>. Just watch out for <ja>国</ja>, which you might expect to rendaku here, but doesn't!

context_sentences.en: Most of the politicians in our country are men.
context_sentences.ja: 我が国の政治家の多くは男性だ。

context_sentences.en: In our country, mandatory vaccination of the population is under consideration.

context_sentences.en: Currently, foreigners without resident status are not allowed to enter our country.

data.meaning_mnemonic:
Here we have <kanji>I</kanji> followed by the particle <ja>が</ja>, giving us a somewhat old-fashioned and stylized way of say <vocabulary>our</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>one's own</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>my</vocabulary>.

One explanation for this is that in ancient Japanese, <ja>が</ja> was used as a possessive particle, much like <ja>の</ja> is in modern Japanese.
data.reading_mnemonic:
You haven't learned this reading for <ja>我</ja> so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Let you present you with <vocabulary>our</vocabulary> <reading>wa</reading>lrus (<ja>わ</ja>). Well it's <vocabulary>my</vocabulary> walrus really, but I'm happy to share.

context_sentences.en: Today's dinner at our house is deep-fried shrimp.
context_sentences.ja: 我が家の今日のディナーはエビフライです。

context_sentences.en: In the end, everyone loves their own child the most.
context_sentences.ja: だれだって、結局我が子が一番可愛いんだよ。

context_sentences.en: The section chief was saying exactly what you said, as if it were his own words.
context_sentences.ja: 課長、あんたの受け売りをそのまま、我が物顔で言ってたよ。

data.meaning_mnemonic:
If you want to <kanji>ride</kanji> in a <kanji>car</kanji>, the <kanji>ticket</kanji> you'll need is a <vocabulary>passenger ticket</vocabulary>, not just any old <vocabulary>ticket</vocabulary>.

This is generally a ticket for public transportation, so think of the "car" here as a train car.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you take a <kanji>ride</kanji> as a <kanji>guest</kanji> (or a <kanji>customer</kanji>), that makes you a <vocabulary>passenger</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic:

A <vocabulary>passenger</vocabulary> gets on at the next stop. Who is it? It's <reading>Jou</reading>rm (<ja>じょう</ja>), the farmhand.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you <kanji>ride</kanji> a <kanji>horse</kanji>, that's <vocabulary>horseback riding</vocabulary> or, in some parts of the world, simply <vocabulary>horse riding</vocabulary>.

Know who loves <vocabulary>horseback riding</vocabulary>? That's right, <reading>Jou</reading>rm (<ja>じょう</ja>) the farmhand. It makes sense, with him being a farmhand and all.

data.meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji and the vocabulary are exactly the same, so they share meanings as well.

This word is often written in katakana as <ja>ページ</ja>, especially in informal writing and online. But you'll also see the kanji version, especially to refer to the pages of printed texts and in more formal writing.
data.reading_mnemonic: This word uses the reading you learned with the kanji.

data.meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji means <kanji>healing</kanji> and the verb version means <vocabulary>to heal something</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to cure something</vocabulary>, and even <vocabulary>to quench a thirst</vocabulary>, both literally and metaphorically. As you can probably guess, this last use has a poetic feel to it.

Like many verbs ending in <ja>す</ja>, this verb is transitive, meaning it's being done to something. So you can use it when you cure an illness, heal a broken heart, or quench your thirst for adventure!
data.reading_mnemonic: <vocabulary>To heal something</vocabulary> it's sometimes necessary to do something <reading><ja>いや</ja></reading> (gross). Even if you dislike it, even if it's gross, you do it anyway, because you want to heal whatever it is.

context_sentences.en: To cure my fatigue and recover quickly, I drank green tea and ate mochi for a week.
context_sentences.ja: 疲れを癒して、早く回復するために、一週間緑茶を飲んだりお餅を食べたりしました。

context_sentences.en: I was healed by Riko-chan's kind smile.

context_sentences.en: Ryoichiro quenched his thirst for knowledge through reading.
context_sentences.ja: 諒一郎は読書によって知識への渇きを癒すことができた。

data.meaning_mnemonic: An <kanji>evil</kanji> <kanji>company</kanji> is actually <vocabulary>our company</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>our humble company</vocabulary>. We're not going to say our company is virtuous, are we? That wouldn't be humble at all. So instead we call it evil, to show our humility.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

data.meaning_mnemonic: What can you see in the <kanji>north</kanji> that looks like a <kanji>ladle</kanji> and is made up of <kanji>seven</kanji> <kanji>star</kanji>s? That's the group of stars we call <vocabulary>the Big Dipper</vocabulary> or, depending on where you are in the world, perhaps <vocabulary>the Plough</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji.

context_sentences.en: The Big Dipper is made up of seven stars.
context_sentences.ja: 北斗七星は七つの星で構成されています。

context_sentences.en: On a clear night, we can see the Big Dipper from our window.

context_sentences.en: This photo is the Big Dipper before dawn on November 3.

data.meaning_mnemonic:
A <kanji>one</kanji> <kanji>ladle</kanji> <kanji>can</kanji> is a <vocabulary>eighteen-liter container</vocabulary>, which is also a <vocabulary>five-gallon container</vocabulary>. That must be one big ladle!

If you live in Japan you've probably seen these. They're rectangular shaped containers made of metal that are used mostly for industrial purposes, for storing liquids like paint, fuel and chemicals. The <ja>斗</ja> actually refers to an old Japanese measurement, which is roughly equivalent to eighteen liters.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. Just watch out for the <ja>一</ja>, which gets shortened to <ja>いっ</ja>.

context_sentences.en: Eighteen-liter containers are used to store things like detergent and oil.
context_sentences.ja: 一斗缶は洗剤や石油などを保管するためのものです。

context_sentences.en: That store has a promotion on five-gallon containers.
context_sentences.ja: その店では、一斗缶のキャンペーンを行っています。

context_sentences.en: Please stack these eighteen-liter containers in the corner over there.
context_sentences.ja: この一斗缶をあそこのコーナーに積んでください。

data.meaning_mnemonic: One <kanji>design</kanji> that you can <kanji>take</kanji> anywhere with you is <vocabulary>cat's cradle</vocabulary>, the game where you loop string around your hands and fingers to create patterns.
data.reading_mnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi for both kanji.

data.meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Stiff</kanji> <kanji>freight</kanji> always has to be paid for in <vocabulary>coin</vocabulary>s, because coins are also stiff. You can't go paying for something stiff with something not stiff, that would make no sense at all.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meanings.meaning: To Be In Light Of Something

data.meaning_mnemonic:
Because the hiragana ends with an <ja>う</ja> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji means <kanji>model</kanji>, and the verb version means things like <vocabulary>to be in light of something</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to take something into account</vocabulary>. If something is your model, you're taking it into account, and it's in light of it that you make your decisions.

This verb is transitive, meaning that it can take a direct object, but you'll probably see it used more with the particle <ja>に</ja>. It's a pretty formal word so you'll mostly come across it in official, written contexts.
data.reading_mnemonic:
This verb uses the kun'yomi of the kanji. You haven't learned that yet, so here's mnemonic to help you:

If you want <vocabulary>to take something into account</vocabulary>, you'll need to <reading>考</reading>える (<ja>かんが</ja>) about it really hard first. Please think about it really, really carefully, because it's bound <vocabulary>to be in light of something</vocabulary>, and we need to know what that something is.

context_sentences.en: In light of the fact that this is a free service, there will be a limit to the number of participants.
context_sentences.ja: 無料のサービスであることに鑑み、参加人数には制限を設けさせていただきます。

context_sentences.en: Taking into account the global situation, we are making necessary changes.
context_sentences.ja: 世界の状況を鑑みながら、必要な変更を行っています。

context_sentences.en: In light of the importance of diet for health, we will support all citizens to eat a balanced diet.
context_sentences.ja: 健康のための食事の重要性に鑑みて、すべての国民がバランスのとれた食事ができるようなサポートをしていきます。

data.meaning_mnemonic:
Because the hiragana ends with an <ja>う</ja> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>carve</kanji> and the verb version is <vocabulary>to carve something</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to engrave something</vocabulary>.

This is a transitive verb, meaning it can take a direct object. You engrave letters into a stone, and you carve a scary face into a pumpkin. Those letters and that face are your objects.
data.reading_mnemonic: Imagine trying <vocabulary>to carve something</vocabulary> using a <reading>hoe</reading> (<ja>ほ</ja>). Its long handle makes it a pretty impractical tool for carving. Now imagine all the trouble you have carving with it.

context_sentences.en: There was an image of Buddha carved into the stone.
context_sentences.ja: その石には仏像が彫ってありました。

context_sentences.en: In front of this historic shrine, there's a gate with a swan carved on it.
context_sentences.ja: この由緒ある神社の前には、白鳥が彫られた門がある。

context_sentences.en: At the factory, I'm in charge of engraving text using an engraving machine.
context_sentences.ja: 工場で、彫刻機を使って文字を彫る仕事を担当しています。

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>same</kanji> <kanji>window</kanji> <kanji>meeting</kanji> is a meeting with people who spent a long time gazing out of the same classroom window as you. Who are those people? They're your former classmates, and this is a <vocabulary>class reunion</vocabulary>. It can also mean <vocabulary>alumni association</vocabulary>, which is still something you do with former classmates, so it makes sense.
data.reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for <ja>窓</ja>, so here's mnemonic to help you:

If you have a <vocabulary>class reunion</vocabulary> coming up, you'd better work on your <reading>soul</reading> (<ja>そう</ja>). You want to make a good impression on all your old classmates, right? Well get to work on your soul right now, otherwise they might not be impressed.

context_sentences.en: The day before yesterday, I went to my junior high school class reunion.
context_sentences.ja: 一昨日、中学の同窓会に行ってきました。

context_sentences.en: I received an invitation to my elementary school reunion.
context_sentences.ja: 小学校の同窓会の案内が来た。

context_sentences.en: We would like to ask for the cooperation of all alumni in the activities of our alumni association.
context_sentences.ja: 同窓会活動への同窓生の皆さまのご協力をお願いいたします。

data.meaning_mnemonic: You know that the kanji means <kanji>hug</kanji> and the verb <ja>抱く</ja> means "to hug". This noun is similar, but it usually means carrying by hugging, so <vocabulary>holding in one's arms</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>carrying</vocabulary>. This is one that children use a lot!
data.reading_mnemonic: You learned this reading when you learned the kanji.

context_sentences.en: Big sis, carry me!

context_sentences.en: My daughter sleeps soundly when I hold her in my arms.

context_sentences.en: We chose a carrier for our friend's baby.
context_sentences.ja: 友達の赤ちゃんのために、抱っこひもを選びました。

data.meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji means <kanji>male</kanji> and this also means <vocabulary>male</vocabulary>. It's used for animals, plants, and the like.

Note that this is often written in katakana, as in <ja>オス</ja>.
data.reading_mnemonic: <vocabulary>Male</vocabulary> animals can be kind of pushy, always trying <reading>to push</reading> (<ja>押す</ja>) other animals around, trying to be the alpha and all.

context_sentences.en: Is it true that many male cats are left-handed?
context_sentences.ja: 猫の雄に左利きが多いって本当ですか？

context_sentences.en: Apparently all the puppies that were born were male!
context_sentences.ja: 生まれた子犬、みんな雄だったみたい！

context_sentences.en: The male golden-backed squirrel courts by making a frog-like croaking sound.
context_sentences.ja: タイワンリスの雄は、カエルのような鳴き声を出して求愛します。

auxiliary_meanings.meaning: Lodger Who Pays Nothing For Room And Board

data.meaning_mnemonic: To stay <kanji>alive</kanji> in some <kanji>climate</kanji>s, some have no choice but to be a <vocabulary>freeloader</vocabulary>. That is, <vocabulary>a lodger who pays nothing</vocabulary>. If you live somewhere with an inhospitable climate but you can't afford to pay rent, your only option is to live with someone for free.
data.reading_mnemonic:
This is a slightly unusual case because both kanji use the kun'yomi. You haven't learned that reading for <ja>候</ja> yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

What? You've become a <vocabulary>freeloader</vocabulary>? I can't believe you've gone <reading>so low</reading> (<ja>そうろう</ja>)!

context_sentences.en: If you're going to be a freeloader, you should at least learn to cook.
context_sentences.ja: 居候をするなら、せめて料理くらいは覚えた方がいい。

context_sentences.en: I can't say anything too strongly because I'm staying here for free.
context_sentences.ja: 居候の身だから、あんまり強くは言うことはできないんだよね。

context_sentences.en: So I lost my job and started living as a freeloader.
context_sentences.ja: それで、仕事を失って、居候生活を始めたんです。

data.meaning_mnemonic:
When a <kanji>warm</kanji> temper is applied extra <kanji>thick</kanji>, it leads to a person having a <vocabulary>mild-mannered</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>gentle</vocabulary> personality.

Note that this is a more formal term, so you'll usually encounter it in writing.
data.reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You already know the on'yomi for <ja>温</ja>, but not for <ja>厚</ja>, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember it:

The most <vocabulary>mild-mannered</vocabulary> Tofugu staff has to be <reading>on</reading>ion <reading><ja>こう</reading>いち</ja>. It's an onion that jumps in for こういち whenever he's not at the office. He's the most <vocabulary>gentle</vocabulary> soul you could imagine, never yelling at anyone. The ideal boss, really.

context_sentences.en: My husband does everything at his own pace and has gentle nature.
context_sentences.ja: 夫はマイペースで、温厚な性格です。

context_sentences.en: That person is usually mild-mannered, but when he gets angry, he's scary.
context_sentences.ja: あの人、普段は温厚だけど、怒らせると怖いよ。

context_sentences.en: If anything, I think I am on the mild-mannered side.
context_sentences.ja: どちらかといえば、オレは温厚なほうだと思う。

data.meaning_mnemonic: What's the <kanji>reason</kanji> that something <kanji>come</kanji>s into being? Its <vocabulary>origin</vocabulary>, of course. Nothing can come into the world without a <vocabulary>source</vocabulary>, because it's always <vocabulary>coming from</vocabulary> somewhere.
data.reading_mnemonic:
You didn't learn this reading for <ja>由</ja> so here's a mnemonic to help you:

The best way to get close to the <vocabulary>origin</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>source</vocabulary> of something is to move into a <reading>yu</reading>rt (<ja>ゆ</ja>). Yurts are easy to move around, so you can always get close to the source, wherever that may be.

context_sentences.en: What is the origin of your name?
context_sentences.ja: お名前の由来は何ですか？

context_sentences.en: We use ingredients from natural sources.
context_sentences.ja: 自然由来の材料を使っています。

context_sentences.en: This word comes from Latin.
context_sentences.ja: この単語は、ラテン語に由来しています。

data.meaning_mnemonic: You <kanji>pass through</kanji> somewhere for a <kanji>reason</kanji>, so you're going <vocabulary>via</vocabulary> that place.
data.reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You learned this reading for <ja>経</ja> with the kanji, and you learned this reading for <ja>由</ja> with the word <ja>由来</ja>. If you need an extra reminder for that one, here's a mnemonic just in case:

If you're going <ja>via</ja> an unfamiliar place, I recommend you seek out a <reading>yu</reading>rt (<ja>ゆ</ja>) to stay in. Wherever it is you're going via, you can't go wrong if you stay in a yurt.

context_sentences.en: That's the time I went to Kyoto via Tokyo.
context_sentences.ja: 京都に東京経由で行った時です。

context_sentences.en: You can also go via Osaka.
context_sentences.ja: 大阪を経由しても行けますよ。

context_sentences.en: I think it's best to book your inn via the internet.
context_sentences.ja: 旅館の予約は、インターネット経由で行うのが一番いいと思う。

data.meaning_mnemonic:
The <kanji>reason</kanji> that ties people <kanji>together</kanji> is their <vocabulary>lineage</vocabulary> or their <vocabulary>history</vocabulary>. Lineage and history ties people (especially families) together.

This word can be used for people with a prestigious family history as well as for historic buildings, especially temples and shrines.
data.reading_mnemonic:
You didn't learn this reading for <ja>由</ja> with the kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

If you had good <vocabulary>lineage</vocabulary> you'd never make a <reading>U-ey</reading> (<ja>ゆい</ja>) on the highway. That's dangerous, and people with good lineage and a long history would simply never do such a thing.

context_sentences.en: Kiyomizu Temple in Kyoto is a temple with a long history.
context_sentences.ja: 京都の清水寺は由緒あるお寺だ。

context_sentences.en: Just because he has a prestigious lineage, it doesn't make him a nice person.
context_sentences.ja: 由緒ある家の人でも、いい人だとは限らない。

context_sentences.en: It's the oldest and most venerable shrine in Japan.
context_sentences.ja: 日本で最も古い由緒ある神社です。

data.meaning_mnemonic: Someone or something whose <ja>由緒</ja> (lineage) is <ja>正しい</ja> (correct) is <vocabulary>of honorable lineage</vocabulary>, and <vocabulary>venerable</vocabulary> indeed.
data.reading_mnemonic: You already know the readings for <ja>由緒</ja> and <ja>正しい</ja> so you just need to put them together to read this word.

context_sentences.en: He is from a family of honorable lineage.
context_sentences.ja: 彼は由緒正しい家系の出身です。

context_sentences.en: This place was originally a venerable shrine.

context_sentences.ja: 由緒正しい生まれの女性に恋をしてしまった。

data.meaning_mnemonic: What's <kanji>part</kanji> of an hour? A <vocabulary>minute</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>minutes</vocabulary>! This word is the suffix version of <ja>分</ja>, so it goes after numbers to say how many minutes, and is used for telling the time too.
data.reading_mnemonic: How many minutes of fun (ふん) will you have today? Lots and lots of minutes, I hope! Depending on the number before 分, its pronunciation can change to ぷん, because of rendaku. We're looking for the original reading ふん here though!

context_sentences.en: It generally takes about two minutes.
context_sentences.ja: 大体、二分くらいかかります。

context_sentences.en: Shall we rest for fifteen minutes?
context_sentences.ja: 十五分休みましょうか。

context_sentences.en: That first year student has been hiding under the bed for forty-five minutes.

data.meaning_mnemonic:
What <kanji>kind</kanji>s of <vocabulary>seed</vocabulary>s are you going to sow? Think about all the different kinds of seeds, and the kinds of plants they'll grow into.

This can also mean <vocabulary>source</vocabulary>, as in a source of worry or joy, or even of a good story.
data.reading_mnemonic: Choose your <vocabulary>seed</vocabulary>s carefully, because you love to have a <reading>tan eh?</reading> (<ja>たね</ja>). You love tanning, so you don't want to plant anything that will grow tall and create shade. Choose those seed types carefully, and don't forget about your tan, eh?

context_sentences.en: Over there, I received sunflower seeds.
context_sentences.ja: あそこで、ヒマワリの種をもらいました。

context_sentences.en: Thanks, you've given me a good story to tell.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you pass a <kanji>duty</kanji> on to someone, that means you're going <vocabulary>to entrust something</vocabulary> to that person, or you're going <vocabulary>to delegate something</vocabulary>. In other words, you're going <vocabulary>to leave something to</vocabulary> them, so that they do it for you.
data.reading_mnemonic:
This word uses the kun'yomi of the kanji. You haven't learned that reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

In order <vocabulary>to entrust something</vocabulary> to someone, you need to <reading>make a</reading> (<ja>まか</ja>) list. It's no good delegating tasks if the person has no idea what to do, so be sure to make a list, okay?

context_sentences.en: In this company, even young employees are entrusted with essential tasks.
context_sentences.ja: この会社では、若い会社員にも重要な仕事を任せています。

context_sentences.en: It's really important, so it can't be left to anyone else.

context_sentences.en: If you don't learn to delegate, you'll make things hard for yourself.
context_sentences.ja: 任せることを学ばなければ、自分が大変になりますよ。

auxiliary_meanings.meaning: Leaving A Decision To Someone Else

data.meaning_mnemonic:
This word comes from <ja>任せる</ja>, but without the <ja>る</ja> on the end it's a noun. You also have the honorific <ja>お</ja> on the beginning, which is a clue that you're addressing someone else. So you're entrusting something to the person you're talking to, and this means <vocabulary>leaving decisions to someone else</vocabulary>. This is used a lot in restaurants, where it means <vocabulary>chef's choice</vocabulary> or simply <vocabulary>omakase</vocabulary>. In other words, you're leaving the choice of food to the chef.

It can be used in other contexts, too, like if you leave your haircut up to your stylist or a flower arrangement up to the florist, or even if you follow the recommended program at the gym.
data.reading_mnemonic: You learned this reading with the word <ja>任せる</ja>, so I'll leave this one to you.

context_sentences.en: Can I leave my hairstyle decisions to you?
context_sentences.ja: ヘアスタイルは、お任せでお願いできますか？

context_sentences.en: I made a reservation for a 5000-yen omakase special.
context_sentences.ja: 五千円のお任せコースで予約したよ。

context_sentences.en: If you need legal advice, you can count on me!
context_sentences.ja: 法律の相談は、私共にお任せください！

data.meaning_mnemonic: Do you know how <kanji>suspicious</kanji> <kanji>I</kanji> get if I have an <vocabulary>injury</vocabulary>? I start suspecting everyone around me of having given me the injury. It was you, wasn't it?
data.reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi for both kanji. It also uses the less common reading <ja>け</ja>, which you learned with <ja>怪</ja>, so here's a mnemonic to help you recall this reading:

Remember the suspicious soul and its <reading>ke</reading>ttle (<ja>け</ja>)? Yup, turns out this exact kettle is responsible for the <vocabulary>injury</vocabulary>. Suspicious souls and their kettles...

context_sentences.en: Yesterday, my daughter was injured at school.
context_sentences.ja: 昨日、娘が学校で怪我をしてしまいました。

context_sentences.en: I heard that the cause of that child's serious injury was a banana peel.
context_sentences.ja: あの子の大怪我の原因って、バナナの皮らしいよ。

data.meaning_mnemonic:
If you <kanji>untie</kanji> something that's <kanji>frozen</kanji>, you're <vocabulary>thawing</vocabulary> it. The best way to go about <vocabulary>defrosting</vocabulary> anything is always to untie it first.

In the context of computer files, this word can also mean <vocabulary>unzipping</vocabulary>. We unzip files in English, but in Japanese we thaw them!
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi for both kanji, so you should be able to read this one on your own.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Something that's <kanji>plentiful</kanji> and <kanji>rich</kanji> is <vocabulary>abundant</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>plentiful</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>rich</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi of both kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context_sentences.en: The new employee has abundant experience.

data.meaning_mnemonic:
If you <kanji>mix</kanji> and <kanji>substitute</kanji> two people, that's a <vocabulary>change</vocabulary> of personnel, or a <vocabulary>substitution</vocabulary>. Perhaps those people are even working in <vocabulary>shift</vocabulary>s, so they mix and substitute each other at regular intervals.

You'll see this word in pretty diverse contexts, because it can refer to anything from a change of political regime, to the substitution of a player during a match, to factory shifts. The underlying meaning is that one person or group is switched out with another.
data.reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for <ja>代</ja> yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

A <vocabulary>change</vocabulary> calls for a <reading>tie</reading> (<ja>たい</ja>). If you're the new company president, or you're going in to work to start your shift, you'd better make sure you look the part, so get that tie nice and straight.

context_sentences.ja: 交代の時に来なかったし、電話をかけても出ないんだ。

data.meaning_mnemonic: The kanji means <kanji>push</kanji>, and this verb means things like <vocabulary>to hold something down</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>to grasp something</vocabulary>. This verb is pretty versatile, and you can use it if you're holding down a piece of paper, holding a cloth to a wound, or grasping a concept.
data.reading_mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, so hopefully you can read this on your own.

data.meaning_mnemonic:
I'm <kanji>offer</kanji>ing to <kanji>stand</kanji> up and announce what's on the <vocabulary>menu</vocabulary> for today. I'll tell everyone about today's <vocabulary>meal plan</vocabulary>.

This word doesn't mean the kind of physical menu you see in a restaurant, but rather a menu, or meal plan, in the sense of the foods you're planning to eat.

I'm actually announcing the <vocabulary>menu</vocabulary> for <reading>con</reading>dors (<ja>こん</ja>). You thought I was going to tell you what's on the menu for humans? No no, that's a surprise. Condors need a heads-up for these things, because meals are extremely important to condors, given their size and everything.

data.meaning_mnemonic: What can you do with <kanji>empty</kanji> <kanji>hand</kanji>s? <vocabulary>Karate</vocabulary>, that's what. Karate is practiced without weapons, so with empty hands!
data.reading_mnemonic:

data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just watch out for  the しゅつ, which gets changed to しゅっ, as many つs do in this situation.

data.meaning_mnemonic:
Here we have <kanji>nothing</kanji>, followed by the verb <ja>なる</ja>. A verb that means "become nothing"? That'll be <vocabulary>to be gone</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to run out</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to be lost</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to disappear</vocabulary>.

This can be translated in various ways depending on the situation, but just remember that it always refers to something changing from being there, to not being there.
data.reading_mnemonic: This uses the kun'yomi reading, which you learned with <ja>無し</ja>, so you should be good to go.

data.meaning_mnemonic:
This word ends with a <ja>う</ja> sound so you can guess it's a verb. The kanji means <kanji>nothing</kanji>, and you'll end up with nothing if you want to <vocabulary>to get rid of something</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to do away with something</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to lose something</vocabulary>.

This verb is transitive, so the action is happening to something. So maybe you're getting rid of debt, or discrimination, or stress... Whatever it is, there's a direct object with this verb!
data.reading_mnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi, which you already learned when you learned the word <ja>無し</ja>.

data.meaning_mnemonic:

Just like plants in spring, your <vocabulary>adolescence</vocabulary> is when you start growing to your full potential! You might even say it's <vocabulary>the springtime of one's life</vocabulary>.

This generally refers to the period when you’re an energetic teenager and young adult. It can have connotations of exhilarating experiences and bittersweet feelings, as well as nostalgic memories.

data.meaning_mnemonic:

data.meaning_mnemonic:

This word is used in all kinds of situations where there's a feeling that something is going to waste, including food, money, time, talent, and opportunities. You can also use it to say that someone is too good for a job, or even for another person. While it's usually written in kana, you'll see it in kanji too.

I wonder what he's going to do with all those question marks once they're ready to harvest. Other people who must have an abundance of question marks are pro baseball player Kinoshita Takuya (<ja>木下 拓哉</ja> a.k.a. <ja>キノタク</ja>) and actor, model, and K-Pop star Terada Takuya (<ja>寺田 拓哉</ja>).

data.meaning_mnemonic:
<kanji>Sedge</kanji> <kanji>field</kanji> is both <vocabulary>Sugahara</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>Sugawara</vocabulary>, the Japanese family names. Sedgefield is a family name (and a place-name) in English too, so that might help you with this one!

This is a very old surname, said to have originated with Nara period scholar Hanishi-no-sukune (<ja>土師宿禰</ja>) who changed his name to Sugawara-no-furuhito (<ja>菅原古人</ja>). Historically, the name has been associated with scholars and writers, including prominent Heian period statesman, scholar, and poet Sugawara-no-michizane (<ja>菅原道真</ja>) and noblewoman, writer, and poet Sugawara-no-takasue-no-musume (<ja>菅原孝標女</ja>), also known more simply as Lady Sarashina in the English speaking world.
data.reading_mnemonic:
The only reading you haven't learned for this name is the irregular <ja>わら</ja> reading for <ja>原</ja>, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

<vocabulary>Sugawara</vocabulary>-san went to <reading>war a</reading> (<ja>わら</ja>) long time ago, but these days he enjoys a quiet life tending to his <kanji>sedge</kanji> <kanji>field</kanji>s.

context_sentences.en: Sugahara's a cool surname, isn't it?
context_sentences.ja: 菅原っていう苗字、なんかかっこよくね？

context_sentences.en: Oh, Sugawara-san, do you have a cold?
context_sentences.ja: あれ、菅原さん、風邪ですか？

context_sentences.ja: 菅原靴店で、オシャレな革靴を買った。

meanings.meaning: To Pour Each Other A Drink

auxiliary_meanings.meaning: To Pour One Another A Drink

data.meaning_mnemonic: <ja>酌む</ja> means "to serve" and the kanji <ja>交</ja> means <kanji>mix</kanji>. What happens if you serve and mix together? You're going <vocabulary>to pour each other a drink</vocabulary> because you plan  <vocabulary>to drink together</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic:
You haven't learned this reading for <ja>交</ja> yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

All the bars are closed so you and your friends are going <vocabuarly>to drink together</vocabulary> in your <reading>ca</reading>r (<ja>か</ja>). You set up a little bar in the back of your car and settle down for some drinks. It's cramped but cosy.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The verb form of <kanji>compose</kanji> is <vocabulary>to compose</vocabulary>. This particular verb is usually used in relation to poetry, and can also mean <vocabulary>to recite</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to sing</vocabulary>, though more in the sense of singing someone's praises than singing a song.
data.reading_mnemonic: This word shares the same origin as <ja>歌う</ja> and <ja>唄う</ja>, and they share the same readings as well.

context_sentences.en: This is a love poem he composed for his girlfriend.

data.meaning_mnemonic:
A <kanji>compose</kanji>d <kanji>song</kanji> is a <vocabulary>poem</vocabulary>, or a <vocabulary>song</vocabulary>. This can also refer to the act of <vocabulary>composing a poem or song</vocabulary>, which makes a lot of sense given the kanji.

This is used particularly when referring to waka poetry.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi for both kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

data.meaning_mnemonic:
If you <kanji>compose</kanji> something with a <kanji>sigh</kanji>, it's because you're experiencing a <vocabulary>deep feeling</vocabulary>. You might express this deep feeling with an <vocabulary>exclamation</vocabulary>, as you <vocabulary>marvel</vocabulary> at the wonders of the world.

This word can be used for a range of deep feelings, good or bad, and can also be used for the expression of those feelings, so you'll notice that the English translation varies quite a bit depending on the context.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi for both kanji. You should be able to read it on your own.

context_sentences.en: Of course, Azusagawa-san is a talented singer, but the lyrics of her songs are also really good.
