data.meaning_mnemonic: The kanji means <kanji>certain</kanji>, but when it's used as a standalone word, or after a family name, it means things like <vocabulary>someone or other</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>you-know-who</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>something</vocabulary>. It's basically a vague way to refer to someone who's name you've forgotten, or you don't want to mention for some reason.
data.reading_mnemonic:
This word uses the kun'yomi of the kanji, and you haven't learned that yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You bump into <vocabulary>someone or other</vocabulary>, and just as you're wondering what on earth her name is, her <reading>nanny gashe</reading>s (<ja>なにがし</ja>) her on the leg. It looks like it hurts. Poor <vocabulary>you-know-who</vocabulary>, whatever her name is. The nanny looks horrified, and is trying to patch her up.

context_sentences.en: This is the story of Yamada someone or other.
context_sentences.ja: これは、山田某の話である。

context_sentences.en: Wasn't it a guy named Suzuki something?
context_sentences.ja: たしか、鈴木某とかいう人じゃなかったっけ？

context_sentences.en: I heard you-know-who from that drama troupe has done it again.
context_sentences.ja: あそこの劇団の某がまた何かやらかしたらしいぞ。

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>certain</kanji> <kanji>country</kanji> is <vocabulary>a certain country</vocabulary>!
data.reading_mnemonic: This word uses the on'yomi for both kanji, and you learned those readings with the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context_sentences.en: I teach in a country that sends a lot of exchange students to Japan.
context_sentences.ja: 日本に留学生を多く送りこんでいる某国で教えています。

context_sentences.en: Azusagawa-san worked as a temporary employee at a certain country's embassy.
context_sentences.ja: 梓川さんは派遣員として某国大使館に勤めていました。

context_sentences.en: We can't shake the suspicion that Sara Sugawara is a spy for a certain country.
context_sentences.ja: 菅原沙羅が某国のスパイであるという嫌疑はぬぐえません。

data.meaning_mnemonic: No surprises here. A <kanji>certain</kanji> <kanji>place</kanji> is <vocabulary>a certain place</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This word uses the on'yomi for both kanji, and you learned those readings with the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context_sentences.en: I went to an event held at a certain place in Tochigi Prefecture.
context_sentences.ja: 栃木県の某所で行われたイベントに行ってきました。

context_sentences.en: Last night, there was a taiko performance by a celebrity at a certain place.
context_sentences.ja: 昨夜、某所にて、有名人による太鼓の演奏会が行われたようです。

context_sentences.en: I was eating at an izakaya in a certain place in Tokyo when I met my girlfriend.
context_sentences.ja: 彼女と出会ったのは、都内某所の居酒屋で食事をしている時だった。

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>certain</kanji> <kanji>family name</kanji> belongs to <vocabulary>a certain person</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This word uses the on'yomi for both kanji, and you learned those readings with the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context_sentences.en: I met with one of the judges.
context_sentences.ja: 審査員の某氏に会いました。

context_sentences.en: A certain person close to the president commented, "We've put ourselves in a difficult situation".
context_sentences.ja: 社長に近い立場の某氏は、「難しい状況にしてしまった」とコメントしている。

context_sentences.en: A certain person told me that Koichi is going to conquer the world one day.
context_sentences.ja: 「こういちはいつか世界を征服する」と某氏が語っていた。

data.meaning_mnemonic: If <kanji>sand</kanji> is <kanji>spread out</kanji> you get the given name <vocabulary>Sara</vocabulary>. You've written your name in sand, right? Now imagine a Sara you know spreading out sand so that it spells her name. Or imagine a pro athlete, like wrestler Doshō Sara (<ja>土性 沙羅</ja>), judoka Asahina Sara (<ja>朝比奈 沙羅</ja>), or ski jumper Takanashi Sara (<ja>髙梨 沙羅</ja>) spreading out the sand. I bet they'd find some skillful ways to do it.
data.reading_mnemonic: This name uses the on'yomi for both kanji, and you learned those readings with the kanji.

context_sentences.en: Sara-san and I bowed to each other and parted ways.
context_sentences.ja: 沙羅さんと会釈をして別れました。

context_sentences.en: Sara is going to plant the seedlings with Takuya.
context_sentences.ja: 沙羅は拓哉と一緒に苗を植えるつもりです。

context_sentences.en: Did you know that the impressionist Sara comes from Nagoya?
context_sentences.ja: ものまね芸人の沙羅さんが名古屋出身だって知ってた？

data.meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Earth</kanji> and <kanji>sand</kanji> is <vocabulary>earth and sand</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>sediment</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word and it uses the on'yomi for both kanji. This on'yomi for <ja>砂</ja> is a bit less common, and you haven't learnt it yet, so here's a mnemnonic to help you:

If there's too much <vocabulary>sediment</vocabulary>, you need to speak to a <reading>sha</reading>man (<ja>しゃ</ja>) about it. Only a shaman has the power to get rid of all that <vocabulary>earth and sand</vocabulary> and get the river flowing again.

context_sentences.en: There's a lot of sediment in the riverbed.
context_sentences.ja: 川底にはたくさんの土砂がたまっている。

context_sentences.en: Due to the tsunami, a large amount of earth and sand flowed into the second-floor classroom.
context_sentences.ja: 津波で大量の土砂が二階の教室に流れ込んだ。

context_sentences.en: After an earthquake there's a danger of landslides.
context_sentences.ja: 地震の後には土砂災害の危険があります。

data.meaning_mnemonic: If <kanji>sand</kanji> makes a lot of <kanji>profit</kanji>, it swells up and becomes <vocabulary>gravel</vocabulary>. They're like the fat cats of the beach.
data.reading_mnemonic:
You learned the reading for <ja>利</ja> with the kanji, but the reading for <ja>砂</ja> is irregular, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You're walking through that big fat <vocabulary>gravel</vocabulary>, when a pile of it starts moving, and something suddenly leaps out at you. It's a... <reading>ja</reading>guar (<ja>じゃ</ja>)! Run!

context_sentences.en: Asphalt is gravel that's hardened with petroleum.
context_sentences.ja: アスファルトは、砂利を石油で固めたものなんですよ。

context_sentences.en: The uranium mine is at the end of this gravel road.
context_sentences.ja: ウラン鉱山はこの砂利道の先にあります。

context_sentences.en: I think it would be a shame to spread gravel over the garden when we could grow vegetables.
context_sentences.ja: 折角野菜を育てられるのに、庭に砂利を敷いてしまうのはもったいないと思うんだけど。

data.meaning_mnemonic: What do we call the <kanji>sun</kanji>'s <kanji>exit</kanji> from the horizon? That'll be the <vocabulary>sunrise</vocabulary>. Imagine the sun exiting the horizon and climbing up into the sky.
data.reading_mnemonic: This uses the kanji's kun'yomi readings, which you've already learned. As long as you remember those, you should be good to go!

context_sentences.en: Then I watched the sunrise from Mt. Fuji.
context_sentences.ja: そして、ふじ山から日の出をみました。

context_sentences.en: It's almost sunrise!
context_sentences.ja: もうすぐ日の出のじかんだよ！

context_sentences.en: That was a really beautiful sunrise, wasn't it?
context_sentences.ja: めっちゃきれいな日の出だったねー！

data.meaning_mnemonic:
It's the <kanji>origin</kanji> of all <kanji>origin</kanji>s, so it's the way it was <vocabulary>originally</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>from the beginning</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>by nature</vocabulary>. You get the idea.

Note that this is frequently written in just hiragana, but you'll encounter the kanji version too!
data.reading_mnemonic: This is just the kun'yomi reading you learned with <ja>元</ja>, but twice, so you should be good to go!

context_sentences.en: This area was originally pink.
context_sentences.ja: ここは元々はピンクだったんだよ。

context_sentences.en: That model used to be a designer, right?
context_sentences.ja: あのモデルさんって、元々はデザイナーだったんでしょ？

context_sentences.en: This club hasn’t been very popular from the beginning.
context_sentences.ja: 元々、このクラブはあんまりポピュラーじゃないからね。

data.meaning_mnemonic:
Your <kanji>origin</kanji> partner is a partner you had originally, but don't have anymore. In other words, this is your <vocabulary>ex-partner</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>former partner</vocabulary>.

Like in English, this word is fairly formal, and it covers any kind of ex-partner, including business and romantic partners.
data.reading_mnemonic: This uses the kun'yomi of <ja>元</ja> and then it's just kana, so you should know how to read this!

context_sentences.en: I got a text from my ex-partner.
context_sentences.ja: 元パートナーからテキストがきた。

context_sentences.en: Oh, it's the same as my ex-partner's necklace.
context_sentences.ja: あ、それ、元パートナーのネックレスといっしょだ。

context_sentences.en: This is a video of me skiing with my ex-partner at Mt. Fuji.
context_sentences.ja: これは、ふじ山で元パートナーとスキーをしたときのビデオだよ。

data.meaning_mnemonic: Things that make your <kanji>heart</kanji> <kanji>strong</kanji> are <vocabulary>reassuring</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>heartening</vocabulary> to hear. You can practically feel your heart becoming stronger in your chest.
data.reading_mnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You learned them when you learned the words <ja>心</ja> and <ja>強い</ja>, so you should be able to read this on your own. Just note that <ja>つよい</ja> gets rendaku'd to <ja>づよい</ja>!

context_sentences.en: This is heartening data!
context_sentences.ja: これは心強いデータですね！

context_sentences.en: Hayashi-san will be a very reassuring partner for you.
context_sentences.ja: 林さんはとても心強いパートナーになるよ。

context_sentences.en: There is nothing more reassuring than having a professional tell me what to do.
context_sentences.ja: プロが教えてくれるなんて、これほど心強いことはないです。

data.meaning_mnemonic: Your <kanji>inside</kanji> <ja>ポケット</ja> is your <vocabulary>inside pocket</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi for the kanji. You learned that reading when you learned the word <ja>内</ja>.

context_sentences.en: This suit jacket doesn't have an inside pocket.
context_sentences.ja: このスーツのジャケットには内ポケットがありません。

context_sentences.en: This notebook fits into the inside pocket of a bag.
context_sentences.ja: このノートは、バッグの内ポケットに入ります。

context_sentences.en: Look, that kid's putting bugs in his inside pocket.
context_sentences.ja: 見て、あの子、内ポケットに虫を入れてるよ！

data.meaning_mnemonic: You've already learned <ja>石</ja>, which means <kanji>stone</kanji>. Add a <ja>ころ</ja> to that, and it becomes a <vocabulary>small stone</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>pebble</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This uses the kun'yomi of <ja>石</ja>, which you've already learned, and adds a bit of hiragana, so you should be able to read this!

context_sentences.en: I'm collecting small stones to paint.
context_sentences.ja: ペイントするための石ころをひろっているんです。

context_sentences.en: Throw this stone at that ninja!
context_sentences.ja: この石ころを、あのニンジャになげるんだ！

context_sentences.en: There are a lot of pebbles on this beach.
context_sentences.ja: このビーチ、石ころがたくさんあるね。

data.meaning_mnemonic: You already know that <ja>町</ja> means "town" and that <ja>外れ</ja> means "extremity" or "outskirts", and this is just a combination of the two. So this means the <vocabulary>outskirts of town</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: You've already learned both <ja>町</ja> and <ja>外れ</ja>, so just combine the two and you get <ja>町外れ</ja> not only in meaning, but also in reading!

context_sentences.en: The man worked at a gas station on the outskirts of town.
context_sentences.ja: 男は町外れにあるガソリンスタンドで働いていた。

context_sentences.en: I'm staying at a hotel on the outskirts of town, that doesn’t even have a convenience store nearby.
context_sentences.ja: 近くにコンビニすらない町外れのホテルにステイしてるんだ。

context_sentences.en: How did you get this far out of town?
context_sentences.ja: こんな町外れまで、どうやって来たの？

meanings.meaning: To Go Out Into The World
To Be Released To The Public

auxiliary_meanings.meaning: To Get Out Into The World
To Be Out In The World

data.meaning_mnemonic: Here we have <kanji>world</kanji> with the particle に, following by the verb <ja>出る</ja> (to go out). Put that together and this means <vocabulary>to go out into the world</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to be published</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be released to the public</vocabulary> in some way or another. Once it's out there in the world, there's even a chance for it <vocabulary>to become renowned</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This uses kun'yomi readings for both kanji, which you should already know by now, so I think you're good to go!

context_sentences.en: It's a dream come true to have my work published.
context_sentences.ja: 自分の作品が世に出るなんて、夢見たいだ。

context_sentences.en: Once a photo or video goes out in the world, it becomes a digital tattoo and stays on the Internet forever.
context_sentences.ja: 一度世に出た写真やビデオは、デジタルタトゥーとなってずっとネットに残るんだよ。

context_sentences.en: In today's concert, I will perform pieces that have never before been released to the public.
context_sentences.ja: 今日のコンサートでは、今まで世に出る機会がなかった曲たちを演奏します。

data.meaning_mnemonic:
Here you have <kanji>other</kanji> and <kanji>person</kanji> joined together by the particle <ja>の</ja>, which shows that "other" is describing "person". So this means <vocabulary>someone else</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>other people</vocabulary>.

This is more general than <ja>他人</ja>, which you already learned. <ja>他の人</ja> can be anyone that's not the speaker, or not the person being talked about. <ja>他人</ja>, on the other hand, has an added implication that the person is someone unknown or unrelated.
data.reading_mnemonic: This uses the kanji's kun'yomi readings, which you've already learned. As long as you remember those, you should be good to go!

context_sentences.en: Fine, I'll have someone else do it!
context_sentences.ja: いいよ、他の人にしてもらうから！

context_sentences.en: Oh, you don't want it? Then I'll give it to someone else.
context_sentences.ja: え、いらないの？じゃあ、他の人にあげるね。

context_sentences.en: Huh, so you deceived someone else!
context_sentences.ja: へー、それで他の人をだましたんだ！

data.meaning_mnemonic: Adding "third generation" to someone's name means that they are the third generation of people with that name. In this case, the person's name is <ja>ナポレオン</ja> (Napoleon), so this means <vocabulary>Napoleon The Third</vocabulary>, also written as <vocabulary>Napoleon III</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The kanji here are pronounced exactly the same as in the standalone word <ja>三世</ja>. That is, it's a jukugo word which uses the on'yomi for both kanji.

context_sentences.en: Today, we're going to learn about Napoleon The Third.
context_sentences.ja: 今日は、ナポレオン三世について学びましょう。

context_sentences.en: Napoleon III was born in the year 1808.
context_sentences.ja: ナポレオン三世は1808年に生まれた。

context_sentences.en: Napoleon Bonaparte is more famous than Napoleon III, isn't he?
context_sentences.ja: ナポレオン・ボナパルトはナポレオン三世より有名ですよね。

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>self</kanji> <kanji>photograph</kanji> is exactly that: a <vocabulary>selfie</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This word uses the on'yomi of <ja>自</ja>, which you learned with the kanji, and the kun'yomi of <ja>撮</ja>, which you learned with the word <ja>撮る</ja>. Though it's a bit of an unusual combo, you can probably guess the first one since it's such a common reading, and the second one because of the <ja>り</ja> on the end. Just watch out for rendaku, which turns <ja>とり</ja> into <ja>どり</ja>.

context_sentences.en: I took a selfie with my smartphone.
context_sentences.ja: スマホで自撮りした。

context_sentences.en: Oh, I don't have my selfie stick.
context_sentences.ja: あれ、自撮り棒がない。

context_sentences.en: Here are some tips on how to take a good selfie easily.
context_sentences.ja: 簡単に上手な自撮りができるコツをお伝えします。

data.meaning_mnemonic: What <kanji>season</kanji>s should you keep an <kanji>eye</kanji> on? The seasons that are <vocabulary>turning point</vocabulary>s in your life. Keep an eye on those seasons, because you don't want to miss the <vocabulary>critical juncture</vocabulary>s and <vocabulary>milestone</vocabulary>s.
data.reading_mnemonic:
This word uses the kun'yomi of both kanji. You haven't learned that yet for <ja>節</ja>, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember it:

The real <vocabulary>turning point</vocabulary> in your life was when you got yourself a <reading>few she</reading>ep (<ja>ふし</ja>). Owning a few sheep was a true <vocabulary>milestone</vocabulary> for you. Now you have all the wool sweaters and cheese you could ever want!

context_sentences.en: The coming-of-age ceremony is an important milestone in one's life.
context_sentences.ja: 成人式は、大切な人生の節目です。

context_sentences.en: Then that year, something happened that would become a major turning point in my life.
context_sentences.ja: そしてその年、人生の大きな節目になる出来事が起こったんです。

context_sentences.en: In hindsight, I guess that was a critical juncture.
context_sentences.ja: 今から思うと、あれが一つの節目だったんだろうね。

data.meaning_mnemonic: Your <kanji>joint</kanji> <kanji>joint</kanji>s are your <vocabulary>various joints</vocabulary>, or even <vocabulary>every joint</vocabulary> in your body, or a specific body part. When we're not talking about the joints in your body, this means something like <vocabulary>various parts</vocabulary>, referring to various parts of a whole.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is just the kun'yomi of <ja>節</ja>, which you learned with <ja>節目</ja>, repeated twice. Keep in mind that the second <ja>ふし</ja> gets rendaku'd to <ja>ぶし</ja>!

context_sentences.en: Every joint in my body is throbbing somehow.
context_sentences.ja: なんか体の節々がズキズキする。

context_sentences.en: That person makes some harsh word choices, huh?
context_sentences.ja: あの人、言葉の節々にトゲがあるよね。

context_sentences.en: Saori woke up with pains in various joints.
context_sentences.ja: 早織は節々の痛みを感じて目を覚ました。
